data.sampled:
This will execute as follows in an ANS Forth system:
```vbnet
   1 2 3   " rotate right by 3"
    ROTOR!     " rotate word underneath top-of-stack"
     2         " second item from top-of-stack is now at bottom"
     1         " first item from top-of-stack is now on top"
      DUP       " duplicate top-of-stack"
    SWAP      " move top-of-stack to bottom"
                             " so it becomes second-to-bottom"
       3         " third item from top-of-stack is now top"
            ROUND>  " round up if result has decimal part"
                                " otherwise drop fractional part"
                        ROTOR! " rotate word underneath new top-item"
                             2         " second item moves above newly created copy"
                          SWAP      " move top two items down one spot"
               OVER    " check for zero flag; branches to address in TOS"
                           " (if not zero), then continue execution here"
                       1         " first item from stack moves back into top position"
```
Note that `ROTOR` is just shorthand for `( >rotate )`, where `>` is the Forth operator used to perform bitwise operations (`>` stands for "greater than"). The `OVER` keyword checks whether the ZF (zero flag) is set, which indicates whether the result was negative or positive. If the result was negative, the program jumps to the address stored in the current top-of-stack (`CALL`). Otherwise, it continues executing at the next instruction following the `OVER`. Finally, note that I assume you would like responses such as "(stack 0)" instead of "(stack [
